lines.text: Fools! Jug-headed fools! Coming out here in Apache country like they was taking a ride down a city street back East. They never learn until they're dead, and then it don't make no never mind.
Walker, were you ever in the Army?
I rode with Hood.
I had you figured for a Reb.
But that's all behind us, Captain. I fight no wars for a lost cause.
It seems like the Army is always nearby, but never there.
Kind of close back there. That little sidewinder was about to draw down on you.
Oh, he was just looking to carve another notch in his gun.
Do you know what the word 'Apache' means? It means enemy. A twenty-four hours a day enemy. An enemy that's anything that walks on two legs.
As mean as they come.
Yeah. I've seen them take a man and cut his feet an make him walk on cactus. And that is merely before they begin to torture him.
I had a partner once who got caught by some of Victorio's Mescaleros. They staked him out on an ant hill, slit his eyelids and then let nature take it's course.
[Vance bridles under Toby Jack's needling]
You know, someday I'm going to get tired of you talking and make you pull that gun. And that will be the last thing you ever do.
Now, he don't mean nothing, Vance. He's young. He'll learn.
He better or he won't get older.
Little man...big mouth.
Big man...big gun. Now, do you want to see how big?

I'm Hoyt Taylor, District Manager for Butterfield. We have a stage going to Lawrenceburg at noon. Just because you ran into Indians back there doesn't mean we'll run into trouble ahead. Isn't that right?
If I know Apaches, there'll be a heap of trouble everywhere.
If that stagecoach don't leave, we are going to be in a lot of trouble. We're going to lose a lot of money.
Yeah, I know. But if those Apaches is on the warpath, I don't aim to end toes up to the sun with a lance through my grizzard for a tombstone.
I wonder why she hid out in a place like Apache Wells.
Well, she'll find nothing but contempt and scorn in this territory. Her reputation goes ahead of her.
And lingers after.
